title: 111_s3936
content: The "States as Energy Leaders for the Future Act" or "SELF Act" defines terms like "eligible entity" and "Secretary" for the Clean Energy Grant Program. The Department of Energy established a program to provide grants to eligible entities for clean energy and carbon reduction measures, including renewable electricity standards, climate action plans, use of alternative vehicles, energy efficiency in public buildings, participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs, and financing for energy efficiency improvements. The Department of Energy offers grants to eligible entities for clean energy initiatives, including tax incentives, financing mechanisms, grid technology updates, and carbon efficiency standards. Eligible entities must be a State, local government, or regional consortium partnering with private sector and non-governmental organizations. The Department of Energy provides grants to eligible entities, such as States, local governments, or regional consortia, in partnership with private sector and non-governmental organizations. These entities must meet requirements set by the Secretary, submit an application, and use grant funds for specified purposes outlined by regulations. The Secretary determines grant recipients based on application information and criteria established through regulations. The Secretary issues regulations specifying eligible uses for grant funds, criteria for grants, application requirements, and a point system for reviewing applications. Considerations include regional energy disparities and clean energy potential. The Secretary will publish an explanation in the Federal Register on how grants awarded under the Act will be objectively evaluated based on specified criteria. Authorization of $5 billion for fiscal year 2011 to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended. Cost offset for clean energy grant program and deficit reduction by denying deduction for major integrated oil companies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include oil related qualified production activities for major integrated oil companies. The amendment also denies deductions for major integrated oil companies. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010.
